contentrichtext.text: {{MedalTableTop}} {{MedalSport | Women's [[Weightlifting at the Summer Olympics|Weightlifting]]}} {{MedalCountry | {{THA}} }} {{MedalCompetition|[[Olympic Games]]}} {{MedalGold | [[2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Athens]] | [[Weightlifting at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Women's 53 kg|– 53 kg]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[World Weightlifting Championships|World Championships]]}} {{MedalGold | [[2003 World Weightlifting Championships|2003 Vancouver]] | – 53 kg}} {{MedalBronze | [[2002 World Weightlifting Championships|2002 Warsaw]] | – 53 kg}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Asian Games]]}} {{MedalSilver| [[Weightlifting at the 2002 Asian Games|2002 Busan]] | – 53 kg}} {{MedalBottom}} '''Udomporn Polsak''' ({{lang-th|อุดมพร พลศักดิ์}}, born October 6, 1981) is a [[Thailand|Thai]] [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifter]]. Udomporn Polsak was born in [[Nakhon Ratchasima]]. She graduated from the [[Bangkok]] College of Physical Education. She won a silver medal in combined lifts at the [[2002 Asian Games]], bronze at the [[2002 World Weightlifting Championships|2002 World Championships]], and gold at the [[2003 Southeast Asian Games]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-13017410_ITM|title= Golden future for Nong Orn.|publisher= ''[[Bangkok Post]]'', Asia Africa Intelligence Wire|date= 2004-08-17|accessdate= 2009-01-22}}</ref><ref name="IAT">{{cite web|title=Polsak Udomporn (THA)|publisher=IAT Weightlifting Database|url=http://www.iat.uni-leipzig.de/datenbanken/dbgwh/daten.php?spid=C2FEF4E689554481B20EE34ABD4C7F99}}</ref> At the [[2003 World Weightlifting Championships]] in [[Vancouver]], [[Canada]], she won two gold medals, with 1 kg in [[snatch (weightlifting)|snatching]] and 0.5 kg total. She was named 2003 Thai Athlete of the Year by the Sports Authority of Thailand.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-19740504_ITM|title= Tavarit, Udomporn voted best athletes of the year.|publisher= ''[[Bangkok Post]]'', Asia Africa Intelligence Wire|date= 2003-12-17|accessdate= 2009-01-22}}</ref> At the [[2004 Summer Olympics]] in [[Athens]] she became the first Thai woman to win an Olympic gold medal, with 97.5 kg snatching and 222.5 kg total.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/low/olympics_2004/weightlifting/3567534.stm|title= Udomporn makes Thai history|publisher= BBC SPORT|date= 2004-08-15|accessdate= 2009-01-22}}</ref> She was given the honor to be the torch lighter at the [[2007 Southeast Asian Games]], held in her country.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/12/06/sports/AS-SPT-SEA-Games.php|title= Thailand adds more gold as SEA Games officially open|publisher= ''[[International Herald Tribune]]''|date= 2007-12-06|accessdate= 2009-01-22|agency= Associated Press}}</ref> == Notes and references == {{reflist}} {{Footer Olympic Champions Weightlifting Women Featherweight}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Polsak, Udomporn | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Weightlifter | DATE OF BIRTH = 1981-10-06 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Polsak, Udomporn}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Olympic weightlifters of Thailand]] <!--yes, sorted by first name, see category--> [[Category:Olympic gold medalists for Thailand]] [[Category:Thai weightlifters]] [[Category:Weightlifters at the 2004 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic medalists in weightlifting]] [[Category:Asian Games medalists in weightlifting]] [[Category:Weightlifters at the 2002 Asian Games]] [[Category:Medalists at the 2004 Summer Olympics]] {{Asia-weightlifting-bio-stub}} {{Thailand-Olympic-medalist-stub}}
